answer_html: \(f'(x) = -\sqrt{x}\sin x + 3x^2 \sqrt{x^3}\sin (x^3)\)and this completes the question.
hints_html:
Review the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus I.

Break up the integral into two integrals using the point 0. Then use chain rule on one integral and flip the other.
hints_latex: Review the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus I.

Break up the integral into two integrals using the point 0. Then use
chain rule on one integral and flip the other.
hints_raw:
Review the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus I.
Break up the integral into two integrals using the point 0. Then use chain rule on one integral and flip the other.
question: 1 (g)
sols_html:
Following the hint, we have

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) &= \int_x^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt \\ &= \int_x^{0} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt + \int_0^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt \\ &= -\int_{0}^x \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt + \int_0^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt \end{aligned}\]

Now, taking derivatives by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus I and using the chain rule on the second integral, we have

\(f'(x) = -\sqrt{x}\sin x + 3x^2 \sqrt{x^3}\sin (x^3)\)

and this completes the question.
sols_latex:
Following the hint, we have

\begin{align*}
f(x) &= \int_x^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt \\
&= \int_x^{0} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt +  \int_0^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt \\
&= -\int_{0}^x \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt +  \int_0^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt 
\end{align*}

Now, taking derivatives by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus I and
using the chain rule on the second integral, we have

$f'(x) = -\sqrt{x}\sin x +  3x^2 \sqrt{x^3}\sin (x^3)$

and this completes the question.
sols_raw:
Following the hint, we have

<math>
\begin{align}
f(x) &= \int_x^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt \\
&= \int_x^{0} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt +  \int_0^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt \\
&= -\int_{0}^x \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt +  \int_0^{x^3} \sqrt{t}\sin t\,dt 
\end{align}
</math>

Now, taking derivatives by the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus I and using the chain rule on the second integral, we have

<math>
f'(x) = -\sqrt{x}\sin x +  3x^2 \sqrt{x^3}\sin (x^3)
</math>

and this completes the question.
